description.standard:
“It's great to be able to thrive in a time when everyone could be in despair,” Marilyn Manson tells Apple Music about releasing his 11th studio album WE ARE CHAOS during the pandemic. “If everyone's stuck in their houses for now, it's my job to entertain them, like I'm some sort of circus performer. But it is my job, and it inspires me to want to make things because I feel I'm running out of things to watch on Apple TV.” In his revealing At Home With interview with Zane Lowe, the veteran shock-rocker discusses being a sensitive artist behind his stage persona, why his 2000 album Holy Wood is his favorite, and working on CHAOS with country artist/producer Shooter Jennings. Manson also shared an exclusive Apple Music playlist of songs—all of which he listens to in his dressing room while he's on tour. Check out a few of his picks below.

PJ Harvey, “Horses in My Dreams”
“It is heartbreaking. But I tend to be a sentimental motherfucker, don't I? People wouldn't expect that from me. That's a record [Stories From the City, Stories From the Sea]. I could listen to the whole thing. There's so many different elements of her that are so soulful.”

Rick Ross, “The Devil Is a Lie” (feat. JAY-Z)
“I had dinner with Rick Ross once, and he said to me, ‘Man, it's been my dream to always work with you.' And I was like, 'What?' But he didn't know that I used to walk out on stage to 'Devil Is a Lie.' And he was really cool. He just seemed very focused and very intelligent about what he wanted to do with music.”

Sleigh Bells, “Infinity Guitars”
“What I do love about that song the most is the rhythm, how it's like singing. And then it goes to four-on-the-floor where the hi-hat comes in the second half. It's such a headbanger; it's almost a metal song. I think it's fantastic.”
description.short: “If everyone's stuck in their houses for now, it's my job to entertain them.”

attributes.name: At Home With Marilyn Manson: The Playlist

editorialNotes.short: “If everyone's stuck in their houses for now, it's my job to entertain them.”

description.standard: Over the course of the ‘90s, indie rock grew up fast. While the first half of the decade was dominated by scruffy, rock-faithful, fuzz-pedal-stomping slackers, by the midway point, a more sophisticated—yet equally subversive—sensibility was taking root among indie-minded artists who harbored no desire to join the mosh pit. Groups like Portishead and Stereolab repositioned vintage-record-collector sounds in strange beat-driven contexts; Belle and Sebastian made bookish folk-pop fashionable; and Blur and Radiohead abandoned their Britpop past for more experimental realms. By decade’s end, even old-guard noisemakers like The Flaming Lips had outgrown their raucous roots in pursuit of increasingly ambitious songcraft.
description.short: The more sophisticated—yet no less subversive—side of the alterna-era.

editorialNotes.name: ’90s Indie Essentials
editorialNotes.standard: Over the course of the ‘90s, indie rock grew up fast. While the first half of the decade was dominated by scruffy, rock-faithful, fuzz-pedal-stomping slackers, by the midway point, a more sophisticated—yet equally subversive—sensibility was taking root among indie-minded artists who harbored no desire to join the mosh pit. Groups like Portishead and Stereolab repositioned vintage-record-collector sounds in strange beat-driven contexts; Belle and Sebastian made bookish folk-pop fashionable; and Blur and Radiohead abandoned their Britpop past for more experimental realms. By decade’s end, even old-guard noisemakers like The Flaming Lips had outgrown their raucous roots in pursuit of increasingly ambitious songcraft.
editorialNotes.short: The more sophisticated—yet no less subversive—side of the alterna-era.

description.standard: Pop maven Sia chooses not to show her face very much, but she proudly wears her musical lineage on her sleeve. When she lets it all out vocally, there’s an echo of Björk’s uninhibited howl and fearless experimentation. And when she jumps genres, we hear Madonna’s willingness to shapeshift while never missing a beat on the dance floor, while Stevie Wonder’s elastic funk and Malcolm McLaren’s playful hip-hop fuel her quest for perfect pop.
description.short: These musical mavericks and shapeshifters fuel the pop maven.

editorialNotes.name: Sia: Influences
editorialNotes.standard: Pop maven Sia chooses not to show her face very much, but she proudly wears her musical lineage on her sleeve. When she lets it all out vocally, there’s an echo of Björk’s uninhibited howl and fearless experimentation. And when she jumps genres, we hear Madonna’s willingness to shapeshift while never missing a beat on the dance floor, while Stevie Wonder’s elastic funk and Malcolm McLaren’s playful hip-hop fuel her quest for perfect pop.
editorialNotes.short: These musical mavericks and shapeshifters fuel the pop maven.

description.standard: If it weren't for Massive Attack, today's musical landscape would be a whole lot different. After forming in the late '80s in Bristol, England, the group helped bring the trip-hop movement into the mainstream with their 1991 album, Blue Lines, bringing together the city's Caribbean influence with elements from soul and hip-hop to create a sound that was unlike anything else. Having worked with an ever-evolving cast of vocalists including Tracey Thorn, Damon Albarn, Liz Fraser, and reggae legend Horace Andy, Massive Attack continue an astonishing legacy with each new release.
description.short: The iconic group that started the trip-hop movement.

editorialNotes.name: Massive Attack Essentials
editorialNotes.standard: If it weren't for Massive Attack, today's musical landscape would be a whole lot different. After forming in the late '80s in Bristol, England, the group helped bring the trip-hop movement into the mainstream with their 1991 album, Blue Lines, bringing together the city's Caribbean influence with elements from soul and hip-hop to create a sound that was unlike anything else. Having worked with an ever-evolving cast of vocalists including Tracey Thorn, Damon Albarn, Liz Fraser, and reggae legend Horace Andy, Massive Attack continue an astonishing legacy with each new release.
editorialNotes.short: The iconic group that started the trip-hop movement.

editorialNotes.name: Massive Attack: Chill
editorialNotes.short: Lean back and relax with some of their mellowest cuts.

description.standard: Sampha's music lies at the crux of soulful traditions. The London singer/songwriter/producer's music is steeped in the UK's foggy moods—Burial's vaporous garage, Massive Attack and Portishead's mournful trip-hop—but his melodic instincts and acoustic colors also draw from ‘80s folkies like Tracy Chapman and Afropop vanguardists like Oumou Sangaré. Looming largest of all is Sade's effortless, melancholy grace.
description.short: Foggy UK electronic and avant-soul savants.

editorialNotes.name: Sampha: Influences
editorialNotes.standard: Sampha's music lies at the crux of soulful traditions. The London singer/songwriter/producer's music is steeped in the UK's foggy moods—Burial's vaporous garage, Massive Attack and Portishead's mournful trip-hop—but his melodic instincts and acoustic colors also draw from ‘80s folkies like Tracy Chapman and Afropop vanguardists like Oumou Sangaré. Looming largest of all is Sade's effortless, melancholy grace.
editorialNotes.short: Foggy UK electronic and avant-soul savants.

description.standard: In the early '90s, an ambient, atmospheric sound began to emerge from rave culture's chill-out rooms and smoky club corners. This bass-driven blend of hip-hop-inflected breakbeats, jazz grooves, dubby tempos, Rhodes licks, and wraithlike vocals spoke to both premillennial anxiety and escapist bliss. Trip-hop was largely British in origin; Bristol's shores in particular provided a backdrop for Portishead's eerie noir, Massive Attack's epic comedowns, and Tricky's murmured incantations. But the woozy deconstructions of Howie B and the baroque flourishes of Lamb and Goldfrapp pushed the genre beyond its ground zero—geographically and stylistically.
description.short: The bass-driven, Bristol-based sound of premillennial anxiety.

editorialNotes.name: Trip-Hop Essentials
editorialNotes.standard: In the early '90s, an ambient, atmospheric sound began to emerge from rave culture's chill-out rooms and smoky club corners. This bass-driven blend of hip-hop-inflected breakbeats, jazz grooves, dubby tempos, Rhodes licks, and wraithlike vocals spoke to both premillennial anxiety and escapist bliss. Trip-hop was largely British in origin; Bristol's shores in particular provided a backdrop for Portishead's eerie noir, Massive Attack's epic comedowns, and Tricky's murmured incantations. But the woozy deconstructions of Howie B and the baroque flourishes of Lamb and Goldfrapp pushed the genre beyond its ground zero—geographically and stylistically.
editorialNotes.short: The bass-driven, Bristol-based sound of premillennial anxiety.
The ghost of goth haunts this trip-hop masterpiece.
editorialNotes.standard: Trip-hop was plenty bleak to begin with, but Massive Attack's third album reached new extremes of desolation. The beetle on the cover is a good indicator of the menace inside. Tempos crawl. Vocals are pitched between a whisper and a growl. Even the milk is black in their midnight world. Hip-hop beats and dub bass come cloaked in paranoid atmospheres, but the all-encompassing sense of dread is never anything less than electrifying. On "Teardrop," featuring Cocteau Twins' angelic Elizabeth Fraser, the storm clouds briefly part—a reprieve that only accentuates the heaviness of the rest.

attributes.name: Empty Files - Angel (Massive Attack Cover) Live in Aste Nagusia 2015
